questions.question:
Question 1: A 50-year-old woman comes to the out-patient with complaints of diminished vision along 
with floaters and flashes. The ophthalmologist uses the following instrument to assess the 
retinal lesions. Which of the following statements is true regarding the ophthalmoscopy done 
using the instrument shown in the image below?

options.a: Area of field in focus is 2 disc diameters.
options.b: The image produced is real and inverted.

questions.explanation:
The instrument shown in the above image is an indirect ophthalmoscope, and the procedure is 
known as indirect ophthalmoscopy. An indirect ophthalmoscope produces an inverted, or reversed, real image of 2 to 5 times 
magnification. The area of field in focus is about 8 disc diameters. It is a binocular, self-illuminated device where the condensing lens is usually required, and 
stereopsis is present.

questions.question: Question 2: Which of the following is a feature of indirect ophthalmoscopy?
questions.explanation: Indirect ophthalmoscope needs a binocular vision.

questions.question:
Question 3: On entering the Ophthalmology OPD for the first time, you notice multiple patients being 
examined using the following instrument. What is this instrument?
questions.explanation:
The image shows a slit lamp. Slit-lamp biomicroscopy is the ideal method to visualize the 
fundus, especially for observing the optic disc changes seen in glaucoma. The lenses used are as follows: • Contact type: Goldmann three-mirror contact lens, modified Koeppe lens • Non-contact type: Convex lens à+60D, +78D, +90D (best lens) 620 
Sold by @itachibot • Hruby lens: planoconcave lens with dioptric power of -58.6 D. Option B: The image given below shows a refractometer. Option C: The image given below shows a keratometer Option A: The image given below shows an ophthalmoscope 621 
Sold by @itachibot

questions.question: Question 4: Which of the following instruments can you use to measure corneal thickness?
questions.explanation:
The pachymeter is used to measure corneal thickness. Options A and D: A keratometer (ophthalmometer) measures the curvature of the anterior surface 
of the cornea at two points about 1.25 mm on either side of its center. 622 
Sold by @itachibot Option C: Specular microscopy is the study of the corneal endothelium under a very high 
magnification (100 times greater than slit lamp biomicroscopy). Endothelium can be analyzed for 
cellular size, shape, density, and distribution. The healthy endothelial cell is a regular hexagon, 
and the normal cell density in a young adult is about 3000 cells/mm2. 623 
Sold by @itachibot

questions.question:
Question 5: In which surgery would you use the instrument shown below? 608 
Sold by @itachibot
questions.explanation:
The image shows a Ziegler knife, which is used to open the lens capsule and aspirate the lens 
material in congenital cataract surgeries.

questions.question: Question 6: All of the following are true about the instrument shown in the image given below except-

options.a: It is used for the localization of a foreign body.
options.b: It is used for the measurement of the angle of the posterior chamber.
options.c: It is used for the demonstration of the extent of peripheral anterior synechiae.
options.d: It provides a mirror image of the opposite angle.

questions.explanation:
The given instrument is an indirect gonioscope, which is used to visualize the angle of the anterior 
chamber, i.e., for gonioscopy, and not the angle of the posterior chamber. Types: • Indirect gonioprism- provides mirror image of the opposite angle. • Direct goniolens- provides a direct view of the angle Application: • To view the angle of the anterior chamber • Localization of the foreign body, abnormal blood vessels, or tumors in the angle • Demonstration of the extent of peripheral anterior synechiae • Direct goniolens can be used during goniotomy

questions.question:
Question 7: A 50-year-old male presented with progressive blurred vision, photophobia, and eye pain. On 
examination, there was conjunctival redness, a mid-dilated pupil, and a shallow anterior 
chamber in the right eye. He has been treated both medically and surgically for the condition 
but showed no improvement. The following procedure incorporates a device to aid drainage. 
Identify the device.
questions.explanation:
The clinical vignette points to a diagnosis of glaucoma not responsive to medical treatment and 
trabeculectomy and the device used is an ex-Press™ glaucoma implant (mini shunt). 624 
Sold by @itachibot It is a form of minimally invasive glaucoma surgery (MIGS) to increase aqueous drainage. Ex-PRESS glaucoma implant is a small stainless steel device. It is inserted under a scleral flap 
during a modified trabeculectomy. Complications such as hypotony are lower than with standard 
trabeculectomy. Glaucoma drainage devices are devices that allow aqueous outflow by establishing communication 
between the anterior chamber and sub-Tennon's space/sub-conjunctival space. While these 
devices were traditionally reserved for high-risk patients, or after trabeculectomy had failed, they 
are becoming increasingly popular. The commonly used devices are as follows: 1. Shunts using episcleral explants • Ahmed glaucoma valve: Silicone • Molteno implant - Polypropylene plate and silicone plate • Baerveldt implant - Silicone 2. Mini-shunts • Ex-Press™ Mini-Shunt: Stainless steel • iStent® - Titanium

questions.question:
Question 8: During a visit to the ophthalmology department, you see the following test being performed 
for visual field charting of a patient. Identify the instrument used from the options given 
below. 610 
Sold by @itachibot
questions.explanation:
The image given above shows a Lister's perimeter. It is used in manual perimetry for visual field 
charting Classification: • Manual: Confrontation, Listers, Campimetry, Goldmann perimeter • Automated: Octopus, Field Master, Humphrey Field Analyzer • Static: Friedman, Automated • Kinetic: Confrontation, Listers, Scotometry, Goldmann The best type is automated perimetry.

questions.question:
Question 9: Which among the following would you use for the measurement of intraocular pressure in a 
patient with a scarred cornea?
questions.explanation:
Tonopen is used for measuring intraocular pressure (IOP) in a scarred cornea. It is a hand-held electronic contact tonometer (a modified version of the older Mackay–Marg 
tonometer). Besides portability, its main advantage is the ability to measure IOP reasonably 
accurately in eyes with distorted or edematous corneas and through a soft contact lens. Types of tonometry: • Indentation tonometry- Reading depends on scleral rigidity, e.g., Schiotz tonometer 625 
Sold by @itachibot • Applanation tonometry- Based on the amount of force needed to flatten or applanate a known 
area of the cornea, Imbert–Fick principle. This is further divided into two types - • Fixed force: IOP is proportional to the area, e.g., Maklakov, Barraquer • Fixed area and variable force: IOP is proportional to force. The most reliable is Goldmann. • Self-measurement: Rebound • Non-contact type: Pulse Air, Air-Puff • Irregular cornea: Tonopen, MacKay–Marg Recent tonometers: • Pascals tonometer (dynamic contour tonometry [DCT]): Contact; used for post-LASIK IOP 
measurement. • Reichert Ocular Response Analyzer®: Non-contact Note: Tonography is a non-invasive technique for determining the facility of aqueous outflow. The image given below shows fluorescein-stained semicircular mires.

questions.question:
Question 10: A first-year ophthalmology resident is asked to counsel the parents of a 1-month-old infant 
diagnosed with a lamellar congenital cataract in both eyes. He discusses the treatment 
options and mentions that the following lens will be used in the surgery. This lens is a 611 
Sold by @itachibot

options.b: Posterior chamber intra ocular lens (modified C-loop type)
options.c: Singh and Worst's iris claw lens
options.d: Posterior chamber intra ocular lens (four loop type)

questions.explanation:
Cataract surgery with an intraocular lens (IOL) implantation is the treatment of choice in 
congenital cataracts. The above image depicts a modified C-loop type of posterior chamber 
intraocular lens (PCIOL) used in such cases. This surgery involves an extracapsular cataract extraction (ECCE) with primary 
posterior capsulorhexis and anterior vitrectomy. After removal of the cataractous lens, a posterior 
chamber intraocular lens (PCIOL) is implanted. PCIOL rest entirely behind the iris. They may be supported and fixed as follows: • Capsular bag fixation of PCIOL (most ideal method) 626 
Sold by @itachibot • Ciliary sulcus fixation • Sclera fixation Parts of the IOL: • The central part overlying the optic axis is called the optic. • The peripheral arms used for placement and stabilization are the haptics. The image given below shows different types of intraocular lens.

questions.question:
Question 11: As an intern posted in the department, you are assisting a senior surgical ophthalmologist for 
cataract surgery on a 72-year-old man. You notice the nursing head pass him the following 
lens for implantation. This is a

options.b: Posterior chamber intra ocular lens (modified C-loop type)
options.c: Singh and Worst's Iris claw lens
options.d: Posterior chamber intra ocular lens (four loop type)

questions.explanation:
The image depicts Kelman multiflex type of anterior chamber intraocular lens (ACIOL). It is 
the most commonly used ACIOL. Anterior chamber IOLs lie entirely in front of the iris and are supported in the angle of 
the anterior chamber. IOL implantation is the method of choice for correcting aphakia. These are associated with a higher incidence of bullous keratopathy. The image given below shows different types of intraocular lens. 627 
Sold by @itachibot

questions.question: Question 12: Identify the given instrument.
questions.explanation:
The given image depicts a Maddox wing. It is an instrument by which the amount of heterophoria 
for near vision can be measured. Methods to examine heterophoria: • Testing for refractive error • Cover–uncover test • Prism bar cover test (PBCT) • Maddox rod test • Maddox wing test • Maddox tangent scale: heterophoria for distance • Measurement of the near point of convergence: Using RAF rule (Normally, it is 70 mm) • Measurement of fusional reserve- done with a synoptophore or prism bar

questions.question:
Question 13: You would identify the instrument shown in the image below as: 613 
Sold by @itachibot
questions.explanation:
The image shows Jackson’s cross cylinder (flip-cross technique) which is used to refine the power 
and axis of the cylindrical lens. Option A: Nagel’s anomaloscope is used to test color vision. 628 
Sold by @itachibot Option C: Maddox rod consists of parallel red or colorless cylinders stacked together. Maddox rod 
test is a macular function test used to measure the degree of heterotropia or heterophoria in cases 
of torsional diplopia. Option D: Retinoscope 629 
Sold by @itachibot

questions.question: Question 14: Identify the instrument.
questions.explanation:
The above instrument is a Maddox rod. Maddox Rod Test A Maddox rod is a specially constructed device, consisting of a series of parallel cylinders, that 
converts a point source of light into a line image. It can be used to test for horizontal and vertical 
deviations, and when used in conjunction with another Maddox rod, for cyclo deviations. A patient is asked to fix on a point light in the center of Maddox tangent scale placed 6 meters 
away. A Maddox rod is placed in front of one eye with the axis of the rod parallel to the axis of 
deviation. The patient will see a point light with one eye and a red line with the other. Due to 
dissimilar images of the two eyes, fusion is broken and heterophoria becomes manifest. The 
number on the Maddox tangent scale where the red line falls will be the amount of heterophoria 
in degrees. 630 
Sold by @itachibot 631 
Sold by @itachibot

questions.question:
Question 15: You can use a stenopaeic slit for all of the following except  
.

options.d: To find out the axis in astigmatism

questions.explanation:
Stenopaeic slit is not used for corneal tattooing. Stenopaeic slit is an ophthalmological instrument that is used in: • Fincham’s test (Option A) : This test is used to differentiate between the colored halos due to 
immature cataract and corneal abnormalities such as corneal edema due to glaucoma. • To find out the axis in astigmatism (option D) for prescribing the correction glasses. • To find out the optimal site for optical iridectomy (option C) for treating cases of central macular 
or leucomatous corneal opacities. Corneal tattooing was done mainly in the past for cosmetic purposes. It is commonly done for 
firm scars of corneal opacities in a eye without any useful vision. The below given image is of stenopaeic slit. 632 
Sold by @itachibot

questions.question: Question 16: What is the investigation shown in the image below?
questions.explanation:
The given image depicts Optical Coherence Tomography (OCT) of a normal macula. It is a non-invasive, noncontact imaging system providing high-resolution cross-sectional images 
of the posterior segment. It uses near-infrared light interferometry to do so.

questions.question:
Question 17: 615 
Sold by @itachibot What is the principle of the test in which the patient is asked to read the chart shown in the 
image below?
questions.explanation:
The given image depicts a duo-chrome test based on chromatic aberration. It is used to refine the 
final sphere in subjective refraction. The patient is asked to compare the clarity of the letters on the green and the red side. If a myopic 
sees the letters of the green side clearer, he is overcorrected. So, +0.25 D sphere is added or 
-0.25D is removed. However, if a myopic sees the letters on the red side clearer, he is 
undercorrected and -0.25 D sphere is added. With optimal spherical correction, the letters on the 
red and green halves of the chart appear equally clear.

questions.question: Question 18: Which optical instrument provides an inverted and reversed image of the retina?

options.d: Goldmann contact lens and slit lamp

questions.explanation:
An indirect ophthalmoscope produces a real, inverted and laterally reversed image of the fundus. All the other instruments mentioned including direct ophthalmoscope, Hruby lens and Goldman 
contact lens produce a virtual and erect image of the fundus.

questions.question:
Question 19: All are true about the instrument shown, except: 616 
Sold by @itachibot
questions.explanation:
633 
Sold by @itachibot The given image is of a phacoprobe showing the needle and the silicone irrigation sleeve. This is 
used in phacoemulsification to break the nucleus into fragments and aspirate them.

questions.question:
Question 20: You see the following examination being performed in the ophthal OPD. What is the 
instrument being used?
questions.explanation:
The image shows Hertel's exophthalmometer. Exophthalmometry: measures protrusion of the apex of the cornea from the outer orbital margin 
(with the eyes looking straight ahead). An absolute protrusion of >20 mm or a difference of >2 mm between the two eyes is labeled 
as proptosis. Instruments used to measure proptosis: • Luedde exophthalmometer • Hertel’s exophthalmometer- most common instrument used. Its advantage is that it measures 
both eyes simultaneously.

questions.question: Question 21: Identify the instrument shown in the image.
questions.explanation:
The given instrument is a gonioscope. It is used to visualize the angle of the anterior chamber (gonioscopy). Types: • Indirect gonioprism- provides a mirror image of the opposite angle • Direct goniolens- provides a direct view of the angle Application: • To view the angle of the anterior chamber 634 
Sold by @itachibot • Localization of foreign body, abnormal blood vessels, or tumors in the angle • Demonstration of the extent of peripheral anterior synechiae • Direct goniolens used during goniotomy

questions.question:
Question 22: While evaluating a child with suspected refractive error, you notice that the ophthalmology 
resident performs a retinoscopy. Which of the following is this test based on?
questions.explanation:
Retinoscopy is an objective method used to determine the error of refraction by applying 
the method of neutralization. It is also called skiascopy or shadow test. Principle: When light is reflected from a mirror into the eye, the direction in which light will travel 
across the pupil will depend upon the eye's refractive state. Distance: Usually, the doctor sits at a distance of 1 meter or an arm's length. Types of retinoscopes: • Priestley–Smith retinoscope • Streak retinoscope The image given below shows a retinoscopy being performed on a patient. 635 
Sold by @itachibot

questions.question: Question 23: Which of the following is true about the instrument shown in the image given below?

options.b: It provides a small field of vision.
options.d: Fundus beyond the equator is visualized

questions.explanation:
The given image shows a Hruby lens, and it provides a small field of vision. It is a planoconcave lens. Diopteric power is -58.6D. It provides a small field of vision, with low 
magnification. Fundus beyond the equator cannot be visualized. 636 
Sold by @itachibot
